abstract.p: Pennsylvania State University is ranked number one in women's NCAA basketball tournament, topping East Regional; Connecticut University is seeded number two in East; seedings in other regionals noted; photo (S)

block.p: THE University of Connecticut is a two-time defending national champion, but the Huskies were not given a No. 1 seeding in the tournament. They will, however, receive a home-court edge of sorts throughout the East Regional because they can reach the Final Four without leaving their home state.

UConn (25-4) missed out on a top seeding for just the second time since it won the first of four national titles in 1995. Seeded No. 2 in the East, the Huskies will begin tournament play next Sunday, facing Penn (17-10), the Ivy League champion, in Bridgeport.

THE University of Connecticut is a two-time defending national champion, but the Huskies were not given a No. 1 seeding in the tournament. They will, however, receive a home-court edge of sorts throughout the East Regional because they can reach the Final Four without leaving their home state.

UConn (25-4) missed out on a top seeding for just the second time since it won the first of four national titles in 1995. Seeded No. 2 in the East, the Huskies will begin tournament play next Sunday, facing Penn (17-10), the Ivy League champion, in Bridgeport.

If UConn defeats Penn, it will play the winner of the Auburn-North Carolina State matchup next Tuesday in Bridgeport. A potential matchup with third-seeded Houston looms in the East semifinals in Hartford.

Penn State (25-5) is seeded No. 1 in the East. If the Nittany Lions and the Huskies advance, they will face each other in the East Regional final in Hartford, the site of several UConn games each season.
The other No. 1 seeded teams are Tennessee (26-3), a six-time national champion, in the Midwest (and the overall No. 1-seeded team); Duke (27-3) in the Mideast; and Texas (28-4) in the West. Page D2.
